Title: The Lost Manuscripts of Medieval Europe: Modelling the Transmission of Texts (LostMa)

This project proposes a groundbreaking investigation into the transmission of written artefacts in medieval Europe, focusing on the evolution of chivalric literature in Romance, Germanic, and Celtic languages. LostMa aims to understand how human cultures evolve through the transmission of texts, determining the role of chance in preservation or loss, and analyzing the copying, transformation, and destruction of manuscript texts. By examining the role of humans in cultural transmission, we will investigate the survival of texts and the formation of cultural canons.

To achieve these objectives, we will employ a novel interdisciplinary approach, combining artificial intelligence, complexity science, and philological expertise. We will analyze the copying and transformation of manuscript texts, using stochastic birth-and-death processes and computer multi-agent simulations to model the transmission of texts. Deep learning techniques will be used for large-scale data collection, focusing on approximately 1000 Old French manuscripts from a corpus of 4000 medieval documents.

By treating the transmission of texts as a process akin to biological evolution or language variation, LostMa will provide new insights into the dynamics of cultural evolution, shedding light on the mechanisms underlying the preservation and loss of written artefacts. The project's outcomes will have significant implications for our understanding of cultural heritage, the development of literary canons, and the role of chance and human agency in shaping our cultural legacy.

Title: The Lost Manuscripts of Medieval Europe: Modelling the Transmission of Texts (LostMa)

This interdisciplinary project, LostMa, seeks to understand the dynamics of cultural transmission through the lens of medieval manuscript texts. By combining artificial intelligence, complexity science, and philological expertise, we will investigate how written artefacts were copied, transformed, or destroyed, and how humans contributed to their preservation or loss. Our case study focuses on chivalric literature in the European context, encompassing Romance, Germanic, and Celtic languages.

We will analyze the transmission of texts as a process akin to the evolution of organisms or language variants, involving innovation/mutation, fixation, or extinction. Our approach will employ stochastic birth-and-death processes, computer multi-agent simulations, and deep learning for large-scale data collection. We will examine approximately 1000 Old French manuscripts, part of a larger corpus of 4000 documents.

LostMa's objectives are to: (1) understand how human cultures evolve through the transmission of written artefacts, (2) determine the role of chance in the preservation or loss of texts, (3) analyze the copying and transformation of manuscript texts, (4) understand the role of humans in cultural transmission, and (5) investigate the survival of texts and the formation of cultural canons.

By modelling the transmission of medieval texts, LostMa will provide new insights into the evolution of human culture, the role of chance and human agency, and the dynamics of cultural heritage. Our findings will have significant implications for the humanities, social sciences, and computational sciences, and will inform the development of new methods for understanding and preserving cultural artefacts.
